Input.posts:
How do you set the working directory permanently on R console, so you don't have to set it every time you open it? windows 7 OS and R 3.1

In RStudio go to Tools -> Global Options and you can change it there. You'll need to restart RStudio before the changes take effect.
Upvotes:
8
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
You might follow this steps to solve the problem permanently 1. Locate the file Rprofile.site on your computer and open it with any editor, say notepad, it should look like what is below. # Things you might want to change # options(papersize='a4') # options(editor='notepad') # options(pager='internal') # set the default help type # options(help_type='text') options(help_type='html') # set a site library # .Library.site <- file.path(chartr('\\', '/', R.home()), 'site-library') # set a CRAN mirror # local({r <- getOption('repos') # r['CRAN'] <- ' http://my.local.cran ' # options(repos=r)}) @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@HERE # Give a fortune cookie, but only to interactive sessions # (This would need the fortunes package to be installed.) # if (interactive()) # fortunes::fortune() 2. Add setwd('C:/where you want to set as work directory') where I put this stuff below @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@HERE You will need to have administrator rights or have full privileges to do edit and save the changes. 3. When you will start R and onward you won't have that problem anymore. Cheers

I am a bit confused as to what is the difference between Numeric & Integer data types. Can someone guide?
Upvotes:
0
Integer is a whole number 1, 2, 3, 4 etc. Numeric could be a whole number (1, 2, 3 or a fraction which is displayed as a decimal e.g. 1.5, 2.5, 3.2 etc) Hope this helps.
Upvotes:
6
One difference is numeric contain whole numbers like 1, 0, 16789 and integer contain decimal numbers like 1.2, 67.09 etc. you can find something here https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2008-January/152838.html
Upvotes:
-6
Thanks a lot, Ashen & Avrajit.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Avrajit, integer does not contain decimal numbers but whole numbers. In fact, you can coerce a floating point number into an integer by using the as.integer() function. :) It is important that you read the difference between modes and data types in R so you won't get confused by certain anomaly in R classes. FWIW, you can use double and numeric interchangeably.

Input.threadtitle: Clarification on Least Common Denominators in Mixing Objects
Input.posts:
Can someone more thoroughly explain how least common denominators work when mixing objects? In the lecture 'Data Types (Part 2)' the following examples are given: y <- c(1.7, 'a') ##character y <- c(TRUE, 2) ##numeric y <- c('a', TRUE) ##character Where the comment indicates which data type is the least common denominator. Why are those the least common denominator? Thank you!
Upvotes:
3
AFAIK it's just the way R is coded. R has to figure out what you mean in each example, and its behavior has to be consistent (logical would help, too). There's no golden rule of 'LCD' in type conversion (again, AFAIK). But since many languages deal with this there are some examples out there to follow. The logic explained in the video is about as good as any. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_conversion#Implicit_type_conversion might help?
